results.title: ‘West Side Story’ Review: In Love and War, 1957 Might Be Tonight
results.abstract: Steven Spielberg rediscovers the breathing, troubling essence of a classic, building a bold and current screen musical with no pretense to perfection.

multimedia.caption: Ansel Elgort and Rachel Zegler as Tony and Maria in Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story.”

results.title: Best Movies of 2021
results.abstract: Even when a film wasn’t great, filmgoing was. But there were some truly wonderful releases, ranging from music docs and musicals to westerns and the just plain weird.
results.byline: By A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis

results.title: Alana Haim Surprised Everyone With Her Movie Debut. Even Herself.
results.abstract: When Paul Thomas Anderson asked her to star in “Licorice Pizza,” the musician had zero acting experience. Now she’s winning rave reviews.

multimedia.caption: Alana Haim said yes immediately to “Licorice Pizza.” A few hours later the doubts crept in. “What if I’m just terrible?” she remembers thinking.
multimedia.copyright: Josefina Santos for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Power of the Dog’ Review: Wild Hearts on a Closed Frontier
results.abstract: In Jane Campion’s staggering take on the western, her first movie in more than a decade, a cruel cowboy meets his surprising match.

multimedia.caption: Benedict Cumberbatch as Phil Burbank in Jane Campion’s “The Power of the Dog.”

results.title: Netflix Holiday Movies Ranked, From Tree Toppers to Lumps of Coal
results.abstract: Is the streaming service delivering goodies in its holiday stockings? We make an assessment.

results.title: ‘Flee’ Review: From Kabul to Copenhagen
results.abstract: A Danish documentary uses animation to tell the poignant, complicated story of an Afghan refugee.

multimedia.caption: Amin, whose family left Afghanistan, as seen in the animated documentary “Flee.”

results.title: ‘Citizen Ashe’ Review: Advantage, Arthur Ashe
results.abstract: This warm, sympathetic documentary portrait traces the career of the tennis champion and pioneer who smashed through history.

multimedia.caption: Arthur Ashe, who became the first African American man to win Wimbledon.

results.title: Paul Verhoeven Has Made a Film About a Lesbian Nun. Jesus Is Next.
results.abstract: The Dutch filmmaker explains what his new movie, based on a real 17th-century sister, has in common with “Showgirls” and “Basic Instinct.”

multimedia.caption: Paul Verhoeven with his “Benedetta” lead, Virginie Efira.

results.title: How Joaquin Phoenix Handles Parenting in ‘C’mon C’mon’
results.abstract: The writer and director Mike Mills narrates a sequence from his film featuring Phoenix and Woody Norman.

results.title: ‘Fatal Distraction’ Review: Parents Go Through the Unthinkable
results.abstract: In the documentary by Susan Morgan Cooper, a father is on trial after his baby dies in the back seat of a hot car.

multimedia.caption: Leanna Taylor, the mother of Cooper, in “Fatal Distraction,” a documentary by Susan Morgan Cooper.

results.title: The Oscars Are Broken. Here’s How to Fix Them.
results.abstract: The ratings flop that was the last ceremony provided useful lessons in what not to do. But there are steps the academy can take for an actually enjoyable evening.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: The Oscars, like this statue, need their luster restored.

results.title: 10 Works of Art That Evaded the Algorithm This Year
results.abstract: Contemplation, not clicks: Our critic looks back on marble sculptures in Rome, songs of “atmospheric anxiety” and the Frick Collection in a new light.

multimedia.caption: From left: A performer in “Catasterism in Three Movements”; one of the Torlonia Marbles; a detail from the refurbished Hôtel de la Marine in Paris.

results.title: 10 Ways I Fed My Fandom(s)
results.abstract: No apologies from our critic-at-large, who found plenty of movies, plays and TV series to nourish the culture nerd within.

results.title: Hollywood Still Matters. This Year’s Best Actors Showed Why.
results.abstract: Even as theaters suffer, cinema has been thriving during the pandemic — thanks to the intimacy movies create between performer and audience.

results.title: Review: ‘Harry Potter’ Back Onstage, Streamlined and Still Magical
results.abstract: “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” returned to Broadway, now in one part instead of two. It may feel smaller, but is no less dazzling.

results.abstract: Our annual celebration of the performances that stayed with us — including Kristen Stewart, Will Smith, Ruth Negga and Benedict Cumberbatch.

results.title: Disney hires Geoff Morrell, a BP executive, as its corporate affairs chief.
results.abstract: Mr. Morrell’s hiring ends a guessing game about who Bob Chapek, Disney’s chief, would select to succeed Zenia B. Mucha, who announced her retirement as Disney’s chief communications officer in July.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Morrell has worked as executive vice president of communications and advocacy at BP and as a spokesman for the Pentagon.
multimedia.copyright: Paul J. Richards/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Hollywood Loves a Monstrous Mommy. Can It Do Her Justice?
results.abstract: Cinema is finally capturing, with uncanny precision and furious energy, more honest and complex versions of the mother.

results.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Landscapers’ and ‘Live in Front of a Studio Audience’
results.abstract: David Thewlis and Olivia Colman star in a true-crime mini-series on HBO. And an ABC special brings back the 1980s sitcoms “The Facts of Life” and “Diff’rent Strokes.”

multimedia.caption: Olivia Colman in “Landscapers.”

results.title: ‘Mrs. Doubtfire’ Review: Nanny Doesn’t Know Best
results.abstract: The new family-friendly musical, adapted from the hit movie, ends up cowering in the original film’s shadow.

multimedia.caption: Rob McClure, center, as Mrs. Doubtfire in the new musical at the Stephen Sondheim Theater.

results.title: Kodi Smit-McPhee on Quiet Confidence, Chronic Pain and ‘The Power of the Dog’
results.abstract: The 25-year-old Aussie delivers a scene-stealing performance as Peter, a bookish boy and aspiring doctor who’s more than he seems.

multimedia.caption: Kodi Smit-McPhee in “The Power of the Dog.” With his performance, “I was always thinking ‘This is too much,’” he said, but the director Jane Campion asked for more.

results.title: ‘The Power of the Dog’: About That Ending
results.abstract: The movie’s subtle conclusion takes a moment to comprehend. But the director, Jane Campion, has a history of working in the realm of suggestion.

multimedia.caption: Benedict Cumberbatch, left, and Kodi Smit-McPhee in “The Power of the Dog.”

results.title: How ‘West Side Story’ Could Make (Even More) Oscar History
results.abstract: After premiering this week, the remake has vaulted into contention, with nominations possible for the film, director Steven Spielberg, Rita Moreno and others.

multimedia.caption: Rachel Zegler in a scene from the new “West Side Story.”

results.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: Including bomb threats, bank robberies and more, the month’s action films pack a wallop.

multimedia.caption: From left, Freddie Highmore, Sam Riley and Astrid Bergès-Frisbey in “The Vault.”

results.title: At Long Last, Onscreen Portrayals of Lesbian Relationships Are Getting Complex
results.abstract: The shift comes after decades of stories that minimized romantic love between women as fruitless, or as some kind of phase.
des_facet: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
The L Word: Generation Q (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Naima Green’s “Untitled (Riis)” (2017), part of a series the artist made at New York City’s Jacob Riis Park, an L.G.B.T.Q. meeting ground. “I’m thinking about queer waterways,” she says. “The ways that the beach is or can become a site of freedom, pleasure and transience for queer people and how we connect.”

results.title: ‘Diary of a Wimpy Kid’ Review: Growing Pains
results.abstract: In this Disney animated feature from the best-selling series of books, the lead character fearfully enters middle school.

results.title: Alec Baldwin Says He Is Not Responsible for Fatal Shooting on ‘Rust’
results.abstract: In an emotional interview with ABC News, the actor asserted, ‘Someone put a live bullet in a gun.’

results.abstract: A look at standout nonfiction films, from classics to overlooked recent works, that will reward your time.

results.title: ‘Try Harder!’ Review: California Overachievement Test
results.abstract: This documentary from Debbie Lum goes inside a top-performing San Francisco public high school to see how students are preparing for the future.

multimedia.caption: Alvan Cai, one of the subjects of the documentary “Try Harder!”

results.title: ‘Torn’ Review: A Climber’s Son Explores His Father’s Legacy
results.abstract: This documentary on the life and death of the mountaineer Alex Lowe demonstrates how unexpected bonds can form around those in grief.

multimedia.caption: The climber Alex Lowe, right, with his son, Max, in the documentary “Torn.”

results.title: ‘Red Pill’ Review: The Horror of a Weekend of Racism and Extremism
results.abstract: Tonya Pinkins is in the director’s chair for this bizarre face-off between political opponents in which rhetoric is the least of the weapons.

results.title: ‘Single All the Way’ Review: Cookie Cutter Christmas
results.abstract: This Netflix holiday rom-com rests its family-friendly shenanigans on a display of chemistry that never materializes.

multimedia.caption: Philemon Chambers and Michael Urie in “Single All the Way.”

results.title: ‘The Advent Calendar’ Review: A December Full of Tricks and Treats
results.abstract: In this Christmastime French horror film, a woman struggles against a powerful, old demon eager to rope her into a Faustian bargain.
